DOC.HEAD: Miller Launches $2 Million `Think When You Drink' Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Miller Brewing Co. will add a new medium this week to its effort to teach consumers to drink responsibly when the beermaker begins a $2 million television advertising campaign for the holidays. The company has used the slogan ``Think When You Drink'' as a tag line in its print advertisements and in taverns and liquor stores, but this year's campaign will be the first time Miller has used the slogan in a television campaign, spokeswoman Elizabeth Conlisk said. ``We looked for a long time for the right tone and the right message,'' Ms. Conlisk said. ``When we did it, we wanted to do it right.'' The television commercials were to start Thursday and run through Dec. 31 and will have a ``warm and cozy feeling to them,'' Ms. Conlisk said. Rather than focusing on the problems irresponsible drinking can cause, the commercials feature traditional American taverns. ``Taverns are places where people have gone for years to have and beer and be with their friends,'' Ms. Conlisk said. ``These commercials make people feel good about that.'' The commercials include the message: ``The next time it's Miller Time for you, we'd like to ask you to do one very simple thing. Be responsible. Think when you drink.'' Milwaukee-based Miller, the No. 2. U.S. brewer, has sponsored educational programs since 1984, based on what Ms. Conlisk called the company's belief that education is the way to reduce alcohol abuse. In the past, Miller has been criticized by anti-drinking activists who claim the brewer has taken an inconsistent and irresponsible approach toward selling its product. In March, for example, Miller was rebuked for running advertisements in college newspapers' advertising supplements intending to capitalize on the rollicking atmosphere of spring vacation. Miller later withdrew and apologized for the ads, which featured tips for men on how to `scam babes'' at the beach. In June, then-U.S. Surgeon General C. Everett Koop issued a set of proposals that would ban alcohol advertisements on college campuses and outlaw ads using celebrities who appeal to youths. Beer industry officials complained Koop's effort amounted to an anti-alcohol campaign. They said while Koop's proposal went too far, the industry as a whole was moving toward empashizing more responsible drinking in an effort to discourage drunken driving. On New Year's Eve, Miller and its distributors will sponsor free bus and taxi rides and designated-driver programs in many U.S. cities to promote responsible drinking and safe driving, Ms. Conlisk said. ``This is really a concerted effort nationwide to reinforce the moderation theme,'' she said. Anheuser-Busch of St. Louis, Miller's top competitor, will use the Budweiser Clydesdales in the brewers' long-running ``Know When to Say When'' advertising campaign.
